awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Food-Water-Energy Nexus: Enabling adaptive integration of technology to enhance community resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
Many cities across the globe are facing difficult challenges managing their food, water and energy systems. The challenges stem from the fact that the issues of food, water and energy are often tightly connected with each other, not only locally but also globally. This is known as the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) nexus.  An effective solution to a local water problem may cause new local problems with food or energy, or cause new water problems at the global level. On a local scale, it is difficult to anticipate whether solutions to one issue in the nexus are sustainable across food, water and energy systems, both at the local and the global scale.  Innovative solutions that encompass the nexus are particularly important to enable cities to better manage their food, water and energy systems and understand the benefits and tradeoffs for different solutions.  

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 29-country initiative through the joint Belmont Forum- Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe.  The Sustainable Urbanization Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy Nexus is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together the fragmented research and expertise across the globe to find innovative solutions to the Food-Water-Energy Nexus challenge.  The call seeks to develop more resilient, applied urban solutions to benefit a much wider range of stakeholders. The rapid urbanization of the world's population underscores the importance of this focus. International partners were invited to develop solutions for this challenge.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

This project aims to generate actionable information by analyzing the distributed production and storage of materials and energy flows into, out of, and within a community/city given their consumption patterns and supply chains associated with various FWE nexuses.  This project will develop a multi-scale modeling framework to address the inter-relationship between multiple stressors affecting the food-water-energy nexus in 3 urban environments, Amsterdam, Orlando, and Paris.  The models will investigate the impacts of increasing metropolitan populations, rapid land use change, shifting social, economic and governance norms, escalating climate variability, and changing ecosystem services within each of the investigated FWE nexus to elucidate the resultant water, carbon, and ecological footprint for each location.  This information should ultimately enable us to understand the trade-offs and balances between various drivers and their impacts on each segment on the nexus which will help to develop scenarios that can optimize the sustainability of the food-water-nexus components for each location.  This information will be used to understand the role of key technologies in different types of nexuses associated with different urban planning scenarios affect the final sustainable solution; and how different social networks help evaluate the acceptance of these potential technologies across different cultural contexts.  This knowledge can then be used to understand both the physical and social resilience of the location and community to potential scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ENLARGE project titled “Enabling large-scale adaptive integration of technology hubs to enhance community resilience through decentralized urban food-water-energy nexus decision support” was a five-year project with a funding support of $838,416 from the National Science Foundation (NSF). ENLARGE’s goal was to explore the evolutionary pathways of urban food-energy-water (FEW) system and catalyze international collaboration through Belmont Forum and Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe. The collaborative framework inspires different member states or regions around the globe to envision possibilities and create innovative research for exploring environmental, economic, and societal impact of interdependent FEW infrastructures in various cities or regions. While the research team in the United States (University of Central Florida and University of Florida) was funded by the NSF, the Dutch team (Delft University of Technology and Amsterdam Institute for Advanced Metropolitan Solutions) was funded by The Dutch Research Council (NWO), and the French team (Institut National de Recherche en Sciences et Technonologie pour l'Environnement et l'Agriculture (IRSTEA, now called INRAe), ECOSEC, Ec ofilae) was funded by French National Research Agency (ANR).

The ENLARGE project sets out to build a framework to analyze cross-sectoral interactions from a quantitative perspective in terms of different modeling skills of future sectoral development, trade-off between costs and benefits via FEW technology integration at varying scales, and their environmental impacts, social equity and resilience concerns in urban transitions. Team members equipped with the multidisciplinary knowledge recognize and realize the importance of international collaborative opportunities across funding agencies (NSF, ANR, and NWO), geographical regions (Europe and North America), national boundaries (USA, France, and the Netherlands), and demographic contexts (Mediterranean Europe, Western Europe, and Southeast US). The research team found out that the Orlando and Miami metropolitan regions have distinctive structure of urban food-energy-water systems with salient industrial symbiosis relationships while the urban forms of Amsterdam (the Netherlands) and Marseille (France) might not be so obvious for a large-scale cross-sector assessment. The US team have identified a number of food deserts in cities with social equity concerns with respect to affordability, awareness, and access to fresh food and assessment was conducted through integrated modeling of future scenarios, where trade-offs between water and carbon footprints have been quantified. This is especially true when the waste management sector in Orlando can be cohesively woven into the urban food-energy-water-waste nexus with synergistic effect. As the project moved forward, Amsterdam was experiencing a unique energy transition process from natural gas to electricity when transforming urban heating systems. The proposed energy-water nexus emphasized integrating perspectives on water use, committed emissions, and energy justice in the city of Amsterdam with profound social and economic impact under climate change and geopolitical conflict (Russia and Ukraine war). At the same time, Marseille was experiencing a port expansion and urban redevelopment plan with a new marine geothermal installation and industrial complex redevelopment, while keeping up its existing food supply chains and regular water treatment systems. The potential yield from urban agriculture through the valorization of grey and yellow water streams for irrigation can be anticipated.

This NSF grant (ICER 1830036) was awarded in 2018 via Belmont Forum collaborative research. Multiple real-world systems in urban transitions have been studied, from building level to city level. A suite of water, carbon and ecosystem services indicators were discovered for applications relevant to different urbanization contexts leading to help compare decentralized vs. centralized decisions for infrastructure transitions across the three urban regions. The project also addresses the targeted research partnership in different multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary settings, bringing together engineers, natural scientists, social scientists, urban planners, industrial partners, and public-private actors representing urban stakeholders for the engagement in all aspects. As a result of this exploration, the research team pivoted from modeling platform development to individual and community engagement, and created different initiatives focused on students, faculty, and stakeholders resulting in abundant journal publications and conference presentations. The published results, shared with the generated knowledge about sustainability factors associated with FEW nexus decision making, outreach experiences, and system efficacy have been disseminated globally. The data analytics and modeling philosophy have been used by the United Nations University.
